qas.question: Has the violence in Burma decreased over the years as the country has tried made democratic strides ?

answers.text: Since the democratic transition began in 2011, there has been continuous violence as 280 people have been killed and 140,000 forced to flee

qas.question: Are the separate religious factions in Burma able to peacefully coexist ?

answers.text: unrest had re-emerged between Myanmar's Buddhist and Muslim communities, with violence

qas.question: What news company  discovered visual evidence of the disdain exhibited by civil employees and civilians in Burma ?

answers.text: BBC News media outlet obtained video footage of a man with severe burns who received no assistance from passers-by or police officers

qas.question: Who recorded the visual evidence on the disdainful incident?

answers.text: footage was filmed by members of the Burmese police force in the town of Meiktila

qas.question: Who was the videotape used as evidence against in Burma ?

answers.text: used as evidence that Buddhists continued to kill Muslims after the European Union sanctions were lifted on 23 April 2013.

context: <a0_0>Since the democratic transition began in 2011, there has been continuous violence as 280 people have been killed and 140,000 forced to flee<a0_0/> from their homes in the Rakhine state. A UN envoy reported in March 2013 that <a1_0>unrest had re-emerged between Myanmar's Buddhist and Muslim communities, with violence<a1_0/> spreading to towns that are located closer to Yangon. The <a2_0>BBC News media outlet obtained video footage of a man with severe burns who received no assistance from passers-by or police officers<a2_0/> even though he was lying on the ground in a public area. The <a3_0>footage was filmed by members of the Burmese police force in the town of Meiktila<a3_0/> and was <a4_0>used as evidence that Buddhists continued to kill Muslims after the European Union sanctions were lifted on 23 April 2013.
